text: <extra_id_0> Interleukin 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling involves the phosphorylation of Stat proteins .

One of the most important cytokines involved in immune response regulation is <extra_id_0> interleukin 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , a potent activator of the proliferation and function of T lymphocytes and natural killer cells .
The mechanisms by which the effects of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are propagated within cells are not understood .

While the binding of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to its receptor was recently shown to lead to the activation of two kinases , <extra_id_0> Jak-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Jak-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , subsequent steps in the signaling pathway to the nucleus that lead to the activation of specific genes had not been characterized .

Since many cytokines that activate Jak kinases also lead to the tyrosine phosphorylation and activation of members of the Stat family of transcription factors , the ability of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to trigger Stat phosphorylation was examined .

Exposure of activated human T lymphocytes or of a natural killer cell line ( NKL ) to <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> leads to the phosphorylation of <extra_id_0> Stat1 alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> Stat1 beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> Stat3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , as well as of two Stat-related proteins , <extra_id_0> p94 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p95 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

<extra_id_0> p94 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p95 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> share homology with <extra_id_0> Stat1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> at the phosphorylation site and in the Src homology 2 ( SH2 ) domain , but otherwise are immunologically distinct from <extra_id_0> Stat1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
These Stat proteins were found to translocate to the nucleus and to bind to a specific DNA sequence .
These findings suggest a mechanism by which <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binding to its receptor may activate specific genes involved in immune cell function .
